page_title: Introduction to Translating and Interpreting Skill Set
text: skills needed in the field. All teaching staff are NAATI-qualified translators or interpreters with current experience to ensure you are equipped with the most current, relevant skills and knowledge. The knowledge and skills you will acquire throughout this skill set and how they can be applied in your career are described in thelearning outcomes. During this online short course, you will take five subjects covering range of introductory skills within translating and interpreting.You'll learn to how to prepare to translate or interpret, build glossaries for translating and interpreting assignments, manage interactions in general settings, read and analyse special purpose English texts to be translated and apply codes and standards to ethical practice. During this online short course, you will take five subjects covering range of introductory skills within translating and interpreting. You'll learn to how to prepare to translate or interpret, build glossaries for translating and interpreting assignments, manage interactions in general settings, read and analyse special purpose English texts to be translated and apply codes and standards to ethical practice. The skill set is recognised by the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters (NAATI). The skill set meets the training prerequisite for translators and interpreters who wish to sit the NAATICertified Provisional Interpretertest and NAATICertified Translatortest or apply for NAATIRecognised Practisingcredentials. Even though there are no formal pathways into this course, there are often other ways you can gain entry. Credit, recognition of prior learning, professional experience and accreditation from a professional body can reduce the duration of your study by acknowledging your earlier, relevant experience.Credit and exemptions will be assessed consistent with the principles of theRMIT Credit Policy.
